children.subject: Also... how much geometry is required for this class?

history.content: 1. Extremely worthwhile -- great overall introduction to computer graphics, some of the math (it's light!) is useful. Also gives a brief overview of some basic light physics, human perception, etc. 2. CS 184 was probably my favorite CS class -- definitely top 3. 3. The class has projects (5 when I took it, plus an open ended final project in lieu of a final). The projects can take a little while (to write, to debug), but they're pretty fun and give you really cool visual results (which provides additional motivation when going to do the projects). CS 184 is listed as one of the highest workload classes... I may be a bit biased (because I found it to be incredibly interesting), but I don't agree with that assessment. CS 162/164 were *significantly* more work. The projects are extendible in a variety of ways though -- you can definitely do a lot more than the bare minimum (and get some extra credit) if you're interested in it. I ended up spending a lot of time on the class, but mostly doing extra stuff. 4. Not at all, as far as I recall. 5. No knowledge of physics is required (aside from basic, "light exists" -- pretty much everything is explained). Some light linear algebra is necessary (useful to have taken EE16A or Math 54), but it's not super intense. Only basic geometry is required. TL;DR: amazing class, definitely recommend taking it if you can.

1. Extremely worthwhile -- great overall introduction to computer graphics, some of the math (it's light!) is useful. Also gives a brief overview of some basic light physics, human perception, etc.
2. CS 184 was probably my favorite CS class -- definitely top 3.
3. The class has projects (5 when I took it, plus an open ended final project in lieu of a final). The projects can take a little while (to write, to debug), but they're pretty fun and give you really cool visual results (which provides additional motivation when going to do the projects). CS 184 is listed as one of the highest workload classes... I may be a bit biased (because I found it to be incredibly interesting), but I don't agree with that assessment. CS 162/164 were *significantly* more work. The projects are extendible in a variety of ways though -- you can definitely do a lot more than the bare minimum (and get some extra credit) if you're interested in it. I ended up spending a lot of time on the class, but mostly doing extra stuff. 
4. Not at all, as far as I recall.

5. No knowledge of physics is required (aside from basic, "light exists" -- pretty much everything is explained). Some light linear algebra is necessary (useful to have taken EE16A or Math 54), but it's not super intense. Only basic geometry is required.

Can someone who has taken CS184 with professor Ren Ng comments on this class?

1. How worthwhile was this course?

2. Did you like it?

3. What's the average workload like with this class?

4. How dependent is this course on 61c?

Thanks!
history.subject: cs184 graphics
